posts.name: Cole Shumaker
posts.cooked:
I want to connect two cylinders end to end. Is there a simple way to tie them together so that they don’t pivot at the joint between the two?

I seem to recall there being a fitting or something that can do this but I can’t remember what it was.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Yes. Aluminum tube. Source stock with ID small enough to be tapped to the correct thread or ID large enough to be a close-ish fit then cross drilled so fasteners can be passed through.

The extra benefit of this approach is all the forces are along the axis of the cylinder, keeping the system far closer to a 2-force member. Therefore less likely to bend something.

(I am assuming you are connecting the “bases” of the cylinders together, not the rods.)

posts.name: Cole Shumaker
posts.cooked: Either rod-rod or base-base is fine. I was actually picturing rod-base but I this this approach makes more sense. I’m just looking to get a 2 stage extension with set travel distances.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
This is an excellent approach for overall positioning imo. Especially if it is easy for your driver to align.

Kinda hard to see, but the “base to base” approach was used here with different length cylinders to provide different arm angles.

pic: 876 Rockpicker CD-Media: Photos

posts.name: Mr V
posts.cooked: Rod to rod will be the easiest, just use a rod coupling nut of the proper size. McMaster-Carr

posts.name: Sarath Jaladi
posts.cooked: While it would be easier, the smaller cross sectional area of the rod makes it inherently more prone to bending and deforming than the base, and coupling two rods together, increasing the length will mean that the assembly of two rods, if extended at the same time will be even more prone to bending. Therefore if possible connecting them base to base is much much better. In the long run bent rods will cause more headache than the trouble of joining the bases upfront, especially if being used for something load-bearing like a three position arm.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Second.

That small coupling nut is in the middle of the curvature of any non-axis forces is not ideal. Especially if the cylinders are exposed.

Fwiw rod to rod also has greater air supply tubing travel for a single cylinder as well.

posts.name: Mr V
posts.cooked: I was just answering the question asked, “Is there a simple way”, “either rod-rod or base-base is fine”. Didn’t say it was the strongest choice, just the easiest and thus most simple way.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Fair, also more than sufficient for fast prototyping

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked: Get a threaded standoff from McMaster and thread both rods together with jamnuts to lock it in place.

posts.name: Cole Shumaker
posts.cooked: Unfortunately we are looking at 34 inches of stroke. So probably not enough

posts.name: Mentor
posts.cooked:
When I was on Team 3489 we used a threaded connector tube one year, and a split shaft clamp another year. Both ideas worked fine.

McMaster-Carr is the complete source for your plant with over 595,000 products. 98% of products ordered ship from stock and deliver same or next day.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Ooh, these are cool, idk why I never bothered to check for them in the first place. thanks for the link!

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
c.shu:

we are looking at 34 inches of stroke

That’s a lot for FRC .  How many times do you plan to actuate this cylinder per match?  If you play with the re.calc pneumatic calculator , I think you’ll find an FRC legal compressor can’t keep up for more than a few actuations of a cylinder that big.

posts.name: Mentor
posts.cooked:
Keep in mind 2 things:

Besides the rod moving, both cylinders move, along with their fittings. Allow enough extra tubing.

Besides the rod moving, both cylinders move, along with their fittings. Allow enough extra tubing.

Nothing orients the cylinders radially. Try to make sure the fittings won’t snag on something.

Nothing orients the cylinders radially. Try to make sure the fittings won’t snag on something.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Yup! Well aware personally, but worth reiterating.

posts.name: mrmummert
posts.cooked:
We did both ways in 2005. Two large cylinders were mounted back to back vertically (to the right in the picture)and we had three smaller ones on our arm (two long ones mounted rod to rod and another one mounted back to back to a long one. 2005 auto 533×800 111 KB

2005 auto 533×800 111 KB

2005 auto 533×800 111 KB

In starting config the arm was retracted and the two large cylinders were extended which held the arm down and inside the frame. We could raise the arm any angle we needed by using the two large cylinders and magnetic reed switches if i remember right. To grab the tetra game piece we simply extended the arm. (there is a very small cylinder on the end which activated a hook to pick up the tetra) then we’d lift the arm (two large cylinders would retract) and place the game piece. I recall it having a 12 foot vertical reach. (from the floor to the hook on the end of the arm) The tower you see in the picture i recall as being at least 8 feet high and you had to lift the tetra (which was 2-3 feet high) above it to get it on the tower. The tetra also weighted about 10 pds.

posts.name: Cole Shumaker
posts.cooked: The bores are relatively small. Only 3/4".
